revision_history.draft:
Ice cracks in the garden’s throat—  
a prism of light fractures—  
a single thread, then another.  

Shadows retreat,  
but not entirely. The puddle’s surface  
holds its breath, then shivers.  

Damp soil exhales—  
a musk, not a scent,  
something older than roots.  

A leaf’s edge, hesitant,  
turns toward the sun.  
It does not yet know  
how to be a leaf.  

The world tilts.  
Not toward bloom,  
but toward the weight  
of a thawing hour.

final_poem:
Ice cracks in the garden’s throat—  
a prism of light splinters—  
a single thread, then another.  

Shadows retreat,  
but not entirely—  
the puddle’s surface  
holds its breath, then shivers.  

Damp soil breathes—  
a musk, not a scent,  
something older than roots.  

A leaf’s edge, hesitant,  
turns toward the sun.  
It does not yet know  
how to be a leaf.  

The world tilts.  
Not toward bloom,  
but toward the weight  
of a thaw,  
of a thawing hour.
